p: The thinking on capabilities originally put forward by Sen, 1993, Sen, 1999 and currently very popular in research on transport and mobilities (see above) is linked to Mullen and Marsden's call for grounding transport justice in virtue ethics (Bertland, 2009). This is because the Ancient Greek notion of eudaimonia plays a major role in both virtue ethics and Sen, 1993, Sen, 1999 Capability Approach. For thinkers such as Aristotle, eudaimonia meant living well (or wellbeing) and was to be achieved through virtuosity and especially by seeking to bring out the best in oneself (Ryff and Singer, 2008). After all, in ancient Greek the prefix eu means good or well, whereas daimon is a noun with multiple and complex meanings that often refers to a quasi-divine, moral mode of being that people can inhabit.
